issuetype.description: A new feature of the product, which has yet to be developed.
issuetype.name: New Feature

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

fields.description:
Hello,

  
I would like all the EBS traffic routed on a dedicated link, eg not impacting
my normal instance traffic.

  
It might be clearer with a picture

  
https://docs.google.com/a/eucalyptus.com/drawings/d/1zA21Sj5ZrVD9nQf0t3JEX9tVi
LtqYAZO3kHf_Q5BqjY/edit

  
Thanks

Olivier
fields.summary: Separate EBS traffic from normal instance traffic

comments.body:
Originally posted on 2012-03-16 16:04:16
Sounds like an excellent idea if we can have the SC on a separate net.
Interesting to see how this would work with the SAN adapter too.

Originally posted on 2012-03-16 16:33:52 by tgerla
I think that's what this property is for:

PROPERTY  vmw.storage.storageinterface  eth0

  
-Tim

Originally posted on 2012-03-16 17:02:29 by wenye
Are you talking about the data traffic or the SC request traffic? SC is not
on the data path. So what's the point of separating them? If you want a
separate network for the data traffic, then NC should use a different
interface to connect to the SANs. That'll be a different architecture from
the one you sketched.

Originally posted on 2012-03-16 17:16:39 by zhill

If you set up your SAN on separate network from the rest of traffic and have an
interface on that network then things will just work. The SC is not in the data
path for EBS so it isn't the issue, the SAN's network config is what is
important. For example, if the SAN is on a separate network and the NC machine
has an interface on that network then things will automatically be routed
correctly without any explicit eucalyptus config. This is a SAN/network config
issue, not a eucalyptus config issue.

Originally posted on 2012-03-21 20:40:16
Thanks all for your reply it was a bad understanding from my side ( + few
others :).

  
I ve tested it and yes it does perfectly.

  
Closing the ticket.

Originally posted on 2012-03-21 20:51:52 by dmitrii
> I ve tested it and yes it does perfectly.

  
Sweet! Thanks for reporting.
I don't think this should be closed.  Linking.
The storage interface option referenced in this ticket was deprecated along with AoE, so it doesn't work.
Ticket now public, thanks Garrett and Neil :)

Bumping :) 

Really we need the storage interface property back but with support for iSCSI and the way we now do things.

Hey guys, we will adding support for ncpaths just like we do for other providers.

The idea would be to define the interface on the NC used for iSCSI traffic and put that interface on a separate data network. That will separate iSCSI and "normal" VM IO.

Hey [~neil],

Do we support separation of traffic in overlay and das today?
[~dshekhawat] - I am told that we do, and it may just be a matter of education / documentation, but I will let [~neil] pitch in.

The ability to set ncpaths to pick the local interface and the target IP to connect to currently only works with SAN backends.

This is related to fixes for multipathing, which is supported only with SAN drivers. 

scpaths has no meaning when iSCSI targets are co-located with the SC (i.e. overlay and DAS).
[~shashi], we should try to prioritize this if its only a minor work.  We need it for our non-SAN reference architectures.
Hi all, what is the update on this item?  Thanks. cc [~neil] [~zhill] [~shashi] [~dshekhawat]

There are no changes in 4.0 on this. It was never prioritized. There may be some ways to achieve this with EDGE and the registration of the SC on a specific network, but nothing explicit in SC configuration for this yet. Probably need to get it on the 4.1 list now if it's needed (sounds like it is).
